thread.title: Jamie Briggs was going to be sacked as junior minister after leadership coup
thread.title_full: Jamie Briggs was going to be sacked as junior minister after leadership coup

title: Jamie Briggs was going to be sacked as junior minister after leadership coup
text:
Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Video will begin in 5 seconds.
Don't play Play now More video Recommended Fugitive manhunt spreads to Victoria
Community mourns little girl's death
Shots fired at chief racing steward's home
Police units dispatched across NSW, Vic border
Melbourne rail crossing plans come under fire
Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
'We have to stay ahead of the pack' Newly appointed Minister for Cities Jamie Briggs says the challenge for Australia will be to keep all our states, including the fastest growing Victoria, livable as we expand.
PT3M31S 620 349 This is the junior minister Malcolm Turnbull didn't want to keep. Fairfax Media has confirmed Jamie Briggs was facing a demotion to the backbench after last month's bruising leadership spill and subsequent reshuffle.
But his immediate ministerial career was saved by Bruce Billson's unexpected decision to turn down a ministerial position because it would have meant being dumped from cabinet.
Mr Briggs was appointed Cities Minister in the reshuffle but Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull first offered the portfolio to Victorian MP Bruce Billson. Mr Billson declined to accept what would have been a demotion from cabinet to sit in the outer ministry and so turned the position down. Mr Turnbull then offered the job to Mr Briggs who accepted.
Jamie Briggs was saved by Bruce Billson's decision to turn down a ministerial position. Photo: Andrew Meares
Liberal sources said had Mr Billson accepted the ministry, it would have been difficult to also find a position for Mr Briggs on the frontbench.
Advertisement Mr Briggs was an Abbott loyalist and a close ally of Joe Hockey who was dumped as federal treasurer and quit Parliament last week . Mr Briggs was a staffer in the former Howard government. He entered Parliament in 2008 in the Mayo byelection, which was caused by the retirement of former foreign minister Alexander Downer.
Mr Briggs has in the past been touted as a potential prime minister as have his Victorian colleagues Kelly O'Dwyer, who entered Parliament a year later, and Josh Frydenberg who arrived in Canberra in 2010. But the Victorian pair leapfrogged Mr Briggs by entering cabinet in last month's reshuffle.
Jamie Briggs denies his injury was the result of any tangle with the table. Photo: Andrew Meares
The day after the leadership spill, Mr Briggs was photographed injured and being pushed around Parliament House in a wheelchair by his South Australian colleague Dr. Andrew Southcott.
He denies he sustained his injury at Tony Abbott's spill night party in the prime ministerial suite where a marble table was shattered after someone danced on top it. Mr Briggs initially said he hurt his leg running but has also suggested he hurt it during events on spill night. He said he had already "limped back" to his own office before the table was broken. Mr Abbott has agreed to pay for the costs after Labor highlighted the damage at Senate estimates.
Follow Latika Bourke on Facebook
